Unilever PLC (ULVR:LSE): Last: 4,358, down 190.5 (-4.19%), High: 4,450, Low: 4,339, Volume: 2.37m

11:21 am

Meanwhile, Unilever suffering from generalised consumer slowdown

PM11:22am

Oh, and it's reduced to blaming the weather

11:23 am
PM11:23am

Poor ice cream sales!

PM11:24am

Have a chunk of RBC on the matter

PM11:24am

When companies start blaming ‘natural disasters in the Americas’ early in a statement, our sense is that it’s not going to be good … and Unilever wasn’t. Q3 organic revenue growth of 2.6% was well below company-compiled consensus expectations of 3.9%, while with 2.8% after 9 months Unilever’s guidance of 3-5% for the year looks like a stretch.
In our view, the seeds of Q3’s poor performance versus expectations were planted with the 130bps reduction in A&P spend in 1H. While natural disasters doubtless played a part, the fact is that Unilever’s Q3 performance came in below expectations in all geographies. The shortfall was all about volumes. Sales growth in Personal care, at 1.8%, was particularly disappointing relative to consensus.
Savings programmes are delivering ‘faster than expected’, which Unilever says ‘is enabling us to step up the level of reinvestment behind our brands’. They need to. Without better top-line performance, we think that the achievement of 2020’s 20% margin target will be jeopardized

11:24 am
PM11:25am

UBS more constructive

PM11:25am

Here's their Q&A thing

PM11:25am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
Unilever reported +2.6% Q3 organic sales (vol +0.2%, price +2.4%), missing consensus expectations for +3.9% (vol +1.7%, price +2.1%). Reported sales missed by -4% (due to FX); see details overleaf. The quarter was negatively impacted by poorer weather in Europe & natural disasters in Americas (US & Mexico). This detracts from a sequential improvement in EMs and in volumes across much of the business (excl. Refreshment). As such, we think today's print is actually better than it might appear at a first glance; and we do not expect material changes to consensus organic sales forecasts for 4Q17 (+4.5%) and 2018 (+4.1%). Nevertheless, the stock is likely to come under pressure in early trading, and FX M2M could drive downgrades to consensus EPS forecasts – we are -2% below company-compiled consensus (although in-line with Reuters consensus).
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
(1) Poor weather and natural disasters had an impact on Europe (organic -1.6%), North America (organic -2.9%) & Mexico – we look for a clarification of the impact in today's conf. call at 8am UK. (2) EM (organic +6.3%) has seen a pick-up in volumes (+1.8%), with China & India accelerating and Brazil getting less bad. (3) However, Asia/AMET/RUB (organic +6.0%, vol +2.7%) missed our expectations – we will be looking for colour around how much of Q2's -80bps drag from India GST/Indonesia calendar impact has reversed in Q3. Divisional details overleaf.
Q: Has the company's guidance/outlook changed?
No: Unilever reiterated FY17 guidance for underlying sales growth in the 3-5% range (cons +3.6%),

100bps underlying EBIT margin (cons +115bps) uplift and strong cash flow. The company is making good progress on the outcomes of the strategic review.

PM11:29am

The most positive comments on the call were about October trends, which management suggested were much better than September. September had been called out as having been the negative surprise in Q3. Bears will focus on the fact that management has not seen FMCG ad spend coming back in H2 and also limited comments around Q4 growth. It is worth highlighting the strong Publicis performance vs peers in North America, which counters the bear case that has US softness at its core.

Trading update here https://www.invest...1710190700040158U/

PM11:37am

Wage and other cost pressures

11:37 am
PM11:38am

And it's quite possibly in trouble on the debt front

PM11:38am

Taking all of these factors into account, we now believe there is a realistic prospect that we will not meet the net debt to EBITDA test contained in our financial covenants for 31st December 2017. As previously announced, we are engaged in constructive and ongoing discussions with our lenders. We have engaged a financial advisor to assist us in these discussions, as well as looking at options to maximise the short and medium term cash generation from the business.

PM11:39am

Liberum trying to be supportive

11:39 am
PM11:39am

But how supportive can their be when the sub-head to their note on the matter says...

PM11:39am

We expect Interserve to be in breach of its current covenants for the FY

PM11:40am

Interserve has announced that it expects to be in breach of its banking covenants of 3.0x net debt EBITDA currently in place for the year-end as a result of weaker trading and an additional provision for the Energy from Waste contracts, where management is providing an additional £35m in FY 2017. However, while this figure is not conclusive, it is better than we and many might have feared. We now expect net debt at the year-end to increase from our previous estimate of £369m to £430m, or 3.8x net debt EBITDA (vs Interserve’s covenants of 3.0x), to reflect the weaker trading performance. The company is no longer guiding to any specific spot or average net debt figures for the year end (we expect £522m of average net debt, vs £492m previously). PwC has been appointed by the company to help with the discussions, which are being described as constructive, as they always are – until they aren’t. We expect discussions to be wide ranging and to include identifying disposal opportunities within the business. Although management confirmed that Equipment Services is a key strategic asset for the company.

11:40 am
PM11:40am

Interserve today announced it is launching a group-wide performance improvement plan, ‘Fit for Growth’, where the goal is to improve margins to industry norms. The company intends to: 1) Look for areas where it can immediately reduce its cost base, although there is no specific cost reduction target yet. Interserve will look to ensure its overhead cost base is fit for purpose for the medium term 2) set a run rate for FY 2018 by identifying any further ‘bad’ contracts within the business to ensure 2018 starts with a good base – which may include the use of further exceptionals and, 3) set a plan for the sectors it wants to be in going forward. Interserve, unlike Carillion, has margins that are significantly below the peer group, providing scope for significant recovery potential.

PM11:41am

Here'e the supportive par..

PM11:41am

In September, Debbie White’s husband bought 65k shares at 76p in a sign of confidence. We believe that like Serco and Mitie thoughts will quickly turn to the recovery potential in the business. In our sum of the parts, we assume a sustainable margin of 5% for Support Services and 1.8% for UK Construction, and apply an EV/EBIT multiple of 6.6x and 5.1x to each. We derive a TP of 150p, down from 180p, but that still offers 160% upside. Clearly there is financial risk. However, we believe that Interserve can muddle through without a debt for equity swap and it has assets to sell. High risk BUY.

PM11:57am

In this regard, Liberum have an interesting note out on chinese propery

11:57 am
PM11:57am

Which is rather important for London listed mining share prices

PM11:57am

The Chinese real estate sector is rolling over as predicted (Download Mining - Calling the rollover in Chinese housing (15 pgs)) with both sales growth and new starts now essentially flat year on year and likely to go negative on tougher comps over the coming months. Chinese property remains the key demand driver for iron ore and the copper globally, not only consuming directly and indirectly the majority of volume in China, but also due to the delta caused by swings in the property cycle.

Following the data this morning and confirmation of slowing credit growth this week, our medium term lead indicators remain firmly negative and we maintain our bearish sector view on the mining equities.

PM11:58am

Sales growth in Tier 3+ cities now falling over in earnest

The key component for a rollover in the Chinese real estate market is slowing sales growth in Tier 3 cities and below; not only do they comprise of c.75% of the floor space sold, but effectively lead prices, new starts and ultimately future commodity demand. Tier 1 & 2 cities in previous cycles have had a strong correlation to Tier 3 cities with a four month lead, but this time Tier 3 cities had remain elevated. With Tier 3 sales strong at the beginning of the year there was a risk that speculative investment had been pushed out of top tier cities by purchasing restrictions and was causing an extended boom in the lower tiers, but that impact appears to have worn off.

11:58 am
PM11:58am

Richard Knights and team

PM11:59am

The bifurcation of the residential and non-residential markets caused by a speculative investment demand boom, and a sharp increase in government purchases of residential property, is now self correcting. Residential sales growth is negative y/y and should continue to drift lower – headwinds from ongoing purchasing restrictions and the the loss of demand from local government purchases remain. 18% of residential floor space sold in 2016 was local governments, but bond issuance has fallen sharply in recent months which should squeeze local government funding. Lagging non residential sales do remain high but they are also rolling off sharply.

PM11:30am

On FMCG, Publicis does not see any improvements in trends in H2. This is contrary to what Omnicom had suggested earlier this week. The latter had mentioned that from conversations with FMCG CEOs it would look like FMCGs' ad spend would accelerate in H2. This is also contrary to what Mediaset Espana (HOLD, TP €10) has stated as they see Health and Beauty ad spend commitments for Q4.
